info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued August 15 at 10:56PM PDT until August 16 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Medford
info.description: ...ISOLATED TO SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS EXPECTED THIS WEEK... ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM TO 11 PM PDT WEDNESDAY FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING ON DRY FUELS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 623 AND 624... ...RED FLAG WARNING WILL EXPIRE AT 11 PM PDT THIS EVENING FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING ON DRY FUELS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 623 AND 624... The National Weather Service in Medford has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from 2 PM to 11 PM PDT Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Any fires that develop have a high probability of spreading rapidly. Abundant lightning can also ignite new fires and strain fire fighting resources. * AFFECTED AREA...Fire weather zones 623 and 624, including portions of the Fremont-Winema National Forest. * THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms are expected across thenorthern portions of these zones this afternoon and evening. Scattered thunderstorms are then expected over a broader area on Wednesday. Storms will be a hybrid of wet/dry on Tuesday and trend wetter on Wednesday, but lightning strikes outside of the wet cores are still likely. * OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusts 30 to 40 mph. * DETAILED URL...View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
info.instruction: Avoid tossing burning cigarettes on the ground, parking hot vehicles on dry vegetation, and using equipment that can cause sparks. Follow all fire restrictions. Find links to restrictions at weather.gov/medford/wildfire. One less spark, one less wildfire. Gather your fire evacuation kit now. Collect essentials you don`t want to lose and prioritize your checklist. Visit ready.gov/kit for more information. Familiarize yourself with your evacuation plan. Where will you go? How will you get there? Who will you call to let others know your are safe? Visit ready.gov/wildfires for more information. A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now or will shortly. These conditions promote rapid spread of fire which may become life threatening. Evacuate if ordered to, or if a fire threatens.
